title: 103_s2233
content:
The Act of 1994 is titled the "Water Resources Development Act" and includes a table of contents. The "Water Resources Development Act" of 1994 includes project authorizations, modifications, cost-sharing for environmental projects, recovery of costs for clean up of hazardous substances, collaborative research, national inventory of dams, hydroelectric power project uprating, engineering and environmental innovations, federal payments for operation and maintenance costs, removal of project features, technical advisory committee, corrections, project deauthorizations, and contract goals for disadvantaged businesses and minority institutions. Sec. 17-22 of the "Water Resources Development Act" of 1994 cover cost-sharing for dam safety work, revocation of a specific section, research and development support for Army Civil Works Program, interagency and international support authority, expansion of a program, and regulatory program fund. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

    For this Act, "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Army.

SEC. 3. PROJECT AUTHORIZATIONS.

    [RESERVED]

SEC. 4. PROJECT MODIFICATIONS.

    [RESERVED]

SEC. 5. COST-SHARING OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROJECTS.

    Amendment to the Water Resources Development Act of 1986 for environmental protection and restoration cost-sharing.

SEC. 6. RECOVERY OF COSTS FOR CLEAN UP OF HAZARDOUS OR TOXIC SUBSTANCES.

    Recovery of costs under the Comprehensive Environmental Response Act for response actions supporting the Army Civil Works Program.

SEC. 7. COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT. Section 7 of the Water Resources Development Act of 1988 is amended to redesignate subsections, delete subsection (e), and add a new subsection regarding temporary protection of technology developed by the Corps of Engineers for potential cooperative research agreements. The Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 allows the Secretary to protect information from dissemination, including exemption from certain regulations, until an agreement is reached or a 2-year period elapses. Information under this act is granted protection under 15 U.S.C. 3710a(c)(7)(B) when involved in cooperative research and development agreements. SEC. 8 amends Section 13 of Public Law 92-367 by authorizing up to $500,000 each fiscal year for the National Inventory of Dams. SEC. 9 pertains to Hydroelectric Power Project Uprating. Hydroelectric power generating facilities at water resources projects can be upgraded for increased efficiency and capacity if economically justified, environmentally sound, and without major changes. This does not affect the authority of the Bonneville Power Administration. The Bonneville Power Administration's authority is not affected by upgrades to hydroelectric power generating facilities at water resources projects. SEC. 10 authorizes up to $3,000,000 annually for innovative engineering and environmental solutions of national importance. The Secretary can also accept additional funds for this purpose. SEC. 11 allows federal lump-sum payments for operation and maintenance costs. The Secretary may provide a payment of the estimated total Federal share of operation, maintenance, replacement, and rehabilitation costs to the non-Federal interest after project completion. The payment amount is based on the present value of Federal payments over the project's life, calculated using an interest rate determined by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Secretary may make a payment to the non-Federal interest for project maintenance under certain conditions outlined in a binding agreement. The agreement must comply with specified requirements and detail the terms for payment, as well as the Federal Government's rights in case of non-compliance by the non-Federal interest. A payment to the non-Federal interest for project maintenance, as outlined in a binding agreement, relieves the Government of future obligations for operation, maintenance, replacement, and rehabilitation costs. SEC. 12. COST-SHARING FOR REMOVAL OF EXISTING PROJECT FEATURES.

Any proposal for modifying an existing water resources project by removing project features impacting project purposes will require the non-Federal sponsor to cover 50% of the modification costs.

SEC. 13. TECHNICAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE.

The Technical Advisory Committee from Public Law 101-640 will be dissolved after the enactment of this Act.

SEC. 14. TECHNICAL CORRECTIONS. SEC. 14. TECHNICAL CORRECTIONS. Amendments made to sections 203(b) and 225(c) of the Water Resources Development Act of 1992. SEC. 15. Project deauthorizations amend Section 1001 of the Water Resources Development Act of 1986 by reducing the number from 10 to 5, changing wording in subsection (b), and adding "planning, designing, or" before "construction." Section 52(a) of the Water Resources Development Act of 1988 is repealed. The Secretary aims to allocate 5 percent of civil works funds for contracts to small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals and historically Black colleges or minority institutions. Competitive procedures will be used to achieve this goal. The Secretary is authorized to use less than full competitive procedures for contracts, paying a price not exceeding fair market cost by 10 percent. They must maximize participation of small disadvantaged businesses, historically Black colleges, and minority institutions. The Secretary can adjust the percentage for industry categories where nondisadvantaged small businesses are being denied opportunities to compete. The Secretary can use less competitive procedures for contracts, with a price not exceeding fair market cost by 10 percent. They must maximize participation of small disadvantaged businesses, historically Black colleges, and minority institutions. The Secretary can adjust the percentage for industry categories where nondisadvantaged small businesses are denied opportunities to compete. Subsection (a) does not apply in a national emergency if the Secretary notifies Congress of the determination and reasons. SEC. 17. COST-SHARING FOR DAM SAFETY WORK. Amendment to cost-sharing for dam safety work. 15 percent of modification costs to be assigned among project purposes as originally determined by the Secretary. SEC. 18. REVOCATION OF SECTION 211, RIVER AND HARBOR ACT OF 1950. Repeal of Section 211 of the River and Harbor Act of 1950. SEC. 19. RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT IN SUPPORT OF ARMY CIVIL WORKERS PROGRAM. Research and development support for Army civil workers program. SEC. 19. Research and development support for Army civil workers program through contracts, agreements, and grants with non-Federal entities for potential commercial applications. SEC. 20. Interagency and international support authority. SEC. 20. The Secretary can support other Federal agencies or international organizations on national issues. The Army Corps of Engineers can provide expertise on water resources, infrastructure, and environmental problems. Up to $3,000,000 can be appropriated annually for this purpose, and additional funds can be accepted from other agencies or organizations. Section 1135 of the Water Resources Development Act of 1986 is amended to allow the Secretary to determine if the operation of water projects has harmed the environment and take measures for restoration if needed. Non-Federal entities may share the cost of any modifications. The non-Federal share of the cost for modifications or measures under this section is 25%. Federal funds for any single modification are limited to $5,000,000. SEC. 22. REGULATORY PROGRAM FUND. The "Army Civil Works Regulatory Program Fund" is established to collect fees for evaluating commercial permit applications and covering expenses related to regulating navigable waters and wetlands. The fees collected are authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary of the Army for this purpose. The Army Civil Works Regulatory Program Fund collects fees for evaluating commercial permit applications and wetlands delineations for major developments. The Secretary of the Army establishes fees to recover costs as provided in appropriation Acts.
